Name: beta-Ionone
Description: Beta-ionone is an ionone that is but-3-en-2-one substituted by a 2,6,6-trimethylcyclohex-1-en-1-yl group at position 4. It has a role as an antioxidant and a fragrance.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) OECD; SIDS Initial Assessment Report For SIAM 20, beta-Ionone (CAS 79-77-6), April 2004, UNEP Publications. Available from, as July 13, 2015: https://www.inchem.org/documents/sids/sids/79776.pdf (2) Gomez E et al; J Agric Food Chem 41: 1669-76 (1993) (3) Guadayol JM et al; J Agric Food Chem 45: 1868-72 (1997) (4) Gallon CZ et al; J Agric Food Chem 61: 7181-87 (2013)
plant_concentrations.Value: beta-Ionone occurs in different types of plants, such as tobacco, the rutacean Boronia megastigma, the caryophyllacean Cerastium candidissimum, the cistacean Cistus monspeliensis, the brassicacean Lepidium meyenii, the fabacean Medicago marina, the oleacean Osmanthus fragrans, the rosacean Rosa bourboniana, the labiatean Thymus serpyllum and in different algae species(1). Apricots (Prunus armeniaca L.) and plums (Prunus salicina Lindl.) were found to contain beta-ionone concentrations of 3-437 ug/kg of fresh fruit tissue(2). beta-Ionone was detected in paprika oleoresin at a concentration of 7.9 mg/kg(3). beta-Ionone was identified in yellow sweet corn (Zea mays var. saccharat)(4).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) USDA; Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Plants with a chosen chemical. beta-Ionone. Washington, DC: US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. Available from, as of July 15, 2015: https://www.ars-grin.gov/duke/

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Cha YJ, Cadwallader KR; Journal Food Sci 60: 19-24 (1995) (2) Chung HY; J Agric Food Chem 47: 2280-87 (1999) (3) Kubota K et al; J Agric Food Chem 39: 1127-30 (1991)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: beta-Ionone was detected in salt-fermented big eyed herring (Harengula zunasi) and hair tail (Trichiurus japonica) viscera at respective concentrations of 463 and 923 ng/g; samples were obtained from fish market in Masan, Korea(1). beta-Ionone was detected in crabmeat (Charybdis feriatus) in the body (0.8 ug/kg) and carapace (32.2 ug/kg)(2). beta-Ionone was identified in the volatiles of clam corbicula(3).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Schwarzbauer J et al; Organic Geochemistry 31: 1713-31 (2000)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: beta-Ionone was qualitatively detected in sediment collected in the German Bight, near the Elbe River, in 1998(1).
